Put on your Whig

Millard A. Fillmore: the Gerald Ford of his generation
By BIFF BURNS
"May God save the country; for
it is evident the people will
not..."
Millard Fillmore, 1844
(upon learning of the defeat of
the Whig party in the Presidential
election)
As every worthy journal
occasionally requires its share of
what may be termed "filler
material", I have been summoned
back from indolent retirement to
play the role of nay-sayer once
more. I crave the gentle-reader's
indulgence (as I pray whatever
gods there be will forgive my
sub-literary self-indulgence) as I
relate My experiences of a
fortnightpast in the City of
Brotherly Love.
The Comte de Baton, an
eighteenth-century French
naturalist, theorized that native
European species of plant and
animal life would undergo a
Process of degeneration in the
New World because of climatic
change. It is my belief that our
own species has indeed
deteriorated here in North
America, not physically in
Button's sense, but culturally and
Spiritually. I do not claim to
understand the process, but I see
the city of Philadelphia as an
appropriate illustration of its
Workings. For whatever pride
that city may rightly retain is
Justified only by the memory of
its past—and not by the reality of
its present condition.
The shrine of religious
toleration in America, the
birthplace of our Constitution,
the home of Franklin, Rush, and
Rittenhouse-THEN. But look at
Philadelphia 200 years later:
graffiti capital of the nation,
haven for the most brutal hockey
team in the NHL, turf of roving
street gang and more subtle
mafiosi, the home of Mike
Douglas (an archetypal figure of
American mediocrity), nominally
ruled by Frank Rizzo
(representative of another kind
of mediocrity and brutalization,
and far more of a menace to
society than Mike Douglas or
even the Flyers). No sages come
out of this city any more, only
Joey Bishops and David
Brenners. We must have been
doing something wrong to
devolve so far in only 200 years,
one brief cosmic instant on the
Darwinian timetable. I came to
Philadelphia to come to terms
With America's failure and,
incidentally, to watch our two
current major-party Presidential
candidates in their first so-called
debate.
Since I was not invited by the
League of Women Voters (those
self-appointed guardians of our
electoral process) to attend the
debate as either spectator or
questioner. I arrived at the
Walnut Street Theatre on the
morning of October 6 in high
dudgeon—yet prepared to accept
the apologies due me for what
could only have been a
monstrous oversight on the part
of that organization. My outrage
only increased, however, as I
found myself first threatened
with a hatpin and then forcibly
escorted from the Theatre by a
Main Line bluestocking and a
Rizzo bluecoat, respectively.
There is no room for
independent scribes in these
debates; one must have
institutional ties in order "to
count" in our society. As I made
my exit, I noticed Jody Powell
stepping out of a limousine. I

P.

'
diem"

Young Millard: who would have
identified myself, explained my
predicament, and received this
reply: "After that hatchet job
did on us back in New
Hampshire, I'm sorry you got off
so easy (sic) today." (If Mr.
Carter's press secretary had only
known how many crucial ethnic
votes in Northwest Baltimore I
control, his whole attitude would
have changed).
After devouring a mediocre
hoagie in a Broad Street beanery,
I registered at a once-prestigious
hotel formerly patronized by the
late John O'Hara, whose
economy of style and banality of
story line I greatly admired, and
by the late American Legion,
whose politics I despised but
whose courageous military
service should have merited a
much happier fate than the one
they received in my hotel. I made
sure that the desk clerk at the
Bedford-Strathmore (name
changed to protect the jinxed)
assigned me the same room
Pennsylvania Governor Milton
Shapp had recently rented and
lived to proclaim "perfectly
safe", a room, incidentally,
equipped with a color television
set. Like millions of my fellow
Americans living in the range of
UHF stations, I passed up the
debate in favor of viewing the
Jerry Lewis art film "Don't Raise
the Bridge—Lower the River",
secure in the knowledge that my
own cultural priorities were in
proper order. Hence, I cannot
analyze the Philadelphia debate.
The Lord knows in advance that
I'm going to behave this way, and
He's forgiven me already for it.
The morning after the unseen
debates, as I walked down the
hall toward the elevator on my
way to check out, I noticed a
sign on the door of a suite which
cried out that here was
something more urgent to check

out. The sign read: Committee to
Re-Elect the President.
Had I entered a time warp?
Was Old Beady Eyes Back on the
Campaign Trail or was this some
pathetic little propaganda mill
for the true believer, perhaps run
by Rabbi Korff? (Answers: Yes,
No,and No)
Upon entering the
Committee's office and
announcing myself as a political
journalist, I was greeted by John
Pendleton Kennedy IV, an
elderly gentleman farmer from
Talbot County, Maryland (no
relation to that upstart
Massachusetts clan), who
described himself as head of the
campaign as well as Chairman of
the Whig Party National
Committee. The posters hanging
from the walls and the literature
being stuffed into envelopes by
the few teenage volunteers made
it perfectly clear to me that the
focus of the Committee's
activities was neither Richard
Nixon nor his hand-picked
successor but a more remote
accidental President: Millard
Fillmore. In the course of my
ensuing investigation of the
Fillmore for President
movement, I searched in vain for
signs of CIA involvement or the
fine hands of Dick Tuck and
Alan Abel, America's foremost
political hoaxters. After a
lengthy discussion with Chairman
Kennedy, I am convinced of the
utter sincerity and idealism of his
movement. An edited transcript
of our interview follows:
Burns; Isn't running a dead man
for President taking the nostalgia
craze a bit too far? Why nominate
someone who has been in his
grave for more than a century?
Kennedy: First of all, we're
Whigs. Always have been and
always will be. We remain loyal
to the principles of our party and

The President served as
Commander-in-Chief for two and
a half years. While we should
have named our organization The
Committee to Give the President
a Four-Year Mandate on His
Own, that's a hard name to
remember. Besides. we were able
to buy up the letterheads from
another organization at a very
reasonable cost.
Burns: I think we're avoiding the
main issue here. President
Fillmore may have been a
capable man and most deserving
of re-election in his own day, but
the fact remains, sir, that you
can't run a dead candidate for
President and your candidate is
dead. Prove to me that your
party and candidate are
still...well, viable.
Kennedy: As far as being dead
goes, President Fillmore still has
more animation in his Buffalo
sepulchre than Ford showed in
the debate last night.
Burns: I didn't see the debate.
Kennedy: And furthermore, it's
been done before—running a
i posthumous • candidate. In 1872,
Horace Greeley appeared on the
ballot as Democratic and Liberal
Republican candidate for
President although he was dead.
And the Courts didn't hassle him
or try to take his name off the
ballot.
Burns: Yes, but Horace was still
alive at the time of his
nomination. It was only an act of
God which prevented him from
being with us on Election Day.
Horace was also associated with
the news media for the greater
guessed it?

A diminishing influence

The Presidential impact on the American economy
By BOB BUCHANAN
Be it one of confidence or
genuine paranoia, the image
projected by the next President
will do as much to influence the
nation's economy as any stand he
may take in accordance with
jobs, spending levels, money
supplies, and the like. But the
impact will likely be less than
what we or the candidates care to
admit.
What matter if that political
• and economic 'bastion of
conservatism -- Gerald Ford -wins, or if voters elect to opt for
the more spendthrift, humanistic
politics and policies of the
Georgian Carter? Will it really
make a difference in the places
where it counts -- on Wall Street.
in welfare and unemployment
compensation lines, and at super
market checkout counters -- if
one man or the other gets the
nod?
In the ballyhoo and electric
atmosphere which pervades the
election week, onlookers tend to
look past the limited effect
which the modern American
Chief Executive can have, both
regarding the economy and the
general condition of national
affairs. We seem to forget that
the executive is but one member
of a web of government, but.
one force matching resources and
wits against the other co-equal
branches of government.
Ultimately, while the next
President will be able to initiate
many pieces of economic
legislation, the Congress will, in
almost all instances, be the final
determiner of .proposals in this
area. The relations with the
Congress which Mr. Carter would
enjoy would place hint in a more
enviable position however, and it
must be pointed out that he
would prove to get more of his
ideas into the governmental

NY R, June 10, 1976.

"It's my Party and I'll cry ifI want to, cry ifI want to, cry ifI want to"
By MIKE DEAK
The trouble with youth is that
it's wasted on the young. --Old
New Jersey adage.
We've come full circle. From
the bombed in the bomb shelter
mentality of the fifties ("Hey
four eyes, let's have a beer bust
Saturday night in your old man's
bomb shelter." "With real girls?"
— Neato-o daddy-o") to the
mindless apathetic paranoia of
the seventies ("Really man who
gives a fuck anymore?") we
Young Americans have returned
to being a race of political
airheads, victims of ideological
vacuums between our ears.
Perhaps with the same naive
optimism that dreamed the
felicitious fantasy of peace ruling
the world in the coming Age of
Aquarius, supposed student
radicals like myself had hoped
the traumatized sixties would
result in a complete
metamorphosis in the nature o f
American existence, not only
Political, but social and cultural
as well. But all that was too
literally a pipe dream; now, to
quote the legendary Professor
Harold Hill, "There's trouble
right here in River City!"
To begin, there is the problem
of perception. No longer is a
personal construct of reality an
acceptable philosophical goal.
After all, who wants to certify a
world of "perpetual murder,
rape, and kidnapping," and in the
same breath (of a misguided
colleague), "marijuana laws are at
best, anachronistic, and at worse,
an invasion of the basic human
right to freedom" (somehow I
don't quite envision Messers.

Jefferson and Franklin had pot
smoking in mind when they
wrote the Declaration of
Independence). Such a
down-trodden juxtaposition of
unequal issues is unfortunately
symptomatic of the intellectual
myopia infecting colleges and
other settings where youth at bay
hang out. If my journalistic
cohort could afford some
corrective lenses, he would surely
not find himself in the middle of
the banana republic rife with
strife and other atrocities that
he describes, but in a plasticene
neon arcade of broken down
pinball machines and
amusements that are no longer
amusing.
On the whole, our youthful
vision of the world outside the
campus is a pretty hopeless one.
In itself, that is not as distressing
as the role we assign ourselves to
play in this aptly named
wasteland. We are not, as some
take fatalistic pleasure in saying,
pawns in a game played by the
powers that be; thinking of this
warped sort presupposes the
existence even of an imaginary
game of chess among the world's
leaders to determine destiny, a
childish concept promoted by
silly movies (Kubrick's "Paths of
Glory" and "Dr. Strangelove" are
notable examples) or kooks who
carry pickets predicting the earth
will meet its doom in twenty-one
days. As any psychologist will
say at the sight of a $20 bill,
paranoia is the prime product of
a guilt complex; in simpler terms,
why should anybody be after me
if I haven't done anything %v/long.
What I'm trying to say in this

article, is that we American
youth have plenty to be guilty
for; not so much for what we've
done, but for what we haven't
done.
Gone are the days when
radicals fed on political Jerry
Rubin sandwiches. All the
activists (the seventies term for
someone crazy enough to
become interested in political
participation) are given now is
piecemeal, an honorary degree
bestowed on a rogue, the
assassination of an ex-Chilean
official, the showing of an
allegedly racist movie, etc., all
curds of lukewarm political
porridge effective enough to
divert the activist's mind off the
more pressing revolutionary
.issues. The majority of students
have indeed lost their
revolutionary zeal; we have
accepted the status quo. I think
we all (with the flukish exception
of those political ghouls, The
Young Republicans) feel a tinge

Candidates TD and TD agreed
to debate in an exclusive press
interview. TD insisted upon
publishing the interview in
Hustler, while his opponent. TD,
refused to consider any magazine
other than Grit , though after
pressure from his staff he
conceded: "Reader's Digest
would be swell."
How to bring the warring
camps together? How to find one
magazine for all? Is TV the only
medium of/by/for all the people?
An interview was to be held, but
how should it be packaged?
"Questions, questions...—
pondered they. "Will there be no
end to such philosophizing?"
Both men, so diverse in political
outlook, reached the same
conclusion: "I must speak so that
every American thinks I am his
spokesman; in speaking for each
American I . speak for all
Americans." This made much
sense in both camps. The
interview would be printed in
Reader's Digest and in Hustler!
Moral and depraved alike would
agree with the views of TD and
TD; a united America would
enter the polls to elect TD and
TD in an historic landslide. But
which TD? Clearly, the winner
would be the man who
represented the views of all
Americans to a greater extent.
Nothing is more confusing in a

It depends on what "life" means....
For most of us, life is a good job,a good wife, a good house,
a good car.
For some (and perhaps for you) this is not enough. The
"good life" somehow is not enough. Life must mean something different: the attempt to live in union with God,to serve
others, to give as totally and as generously as you can.
The Paulists offer a way of life which can satisfy young men
who seek more than the "good life." As a small community
of Catholic priests, we have worked for over a century
throughout the United States and Canada —from Manhattan
to Toronto, from Greensboro to Houston, from Los Angeles
to Fairbanks. Our mission? To speak the message of Jesus
Christ to this modern world: to communicate His shattering
love and overwhelming forgiveness in a time and world where
He so often seems absent.
To do so, we are actively involved in parish work, preaching, adult education, campus ministry, publishing and mass
communications. We are missionaries; we are bridgebuilders. We seek to serve the Gospel in ever new ways.
The Paulist life is not an easy one. But one who dares will
find rewards beyond expectation, satisfactions beyond
dreams. But not complete satisfaction, for we are constantly
searching to make the Gospel real to more people in today's
world.
Don't let your idealism die. Discover what our community
can mean to you.

War is the extension of politics by other ineans, was von
Clausewitz's dictum. The converse i s also true, in my
experience. Politics is the extension of war by other means.
As a pacifist, 1 cannot believe in politics.
I have not always felt thus. I can remember arguing politics
with my friends, when we were in the service. Memory is the
only place where most of them still exist. I was luckier. Still.
I have my political scars from the past on my presently
apolitical self. They're useful reminders, when the political
juices try to flow in me.

seminar in political science under the direction of Dr. Milton

questionnaire representing all departments within the

We'd rather have a candidate who's capable and dead
BURNS from page 1
Yankees destroyed it. Our
.northern. wing fell under the
influence of Free Soilers and
closet abolitionists, wild-eyed
tynes who wanted to tear this
country apart and eventually had
their way. But our principles are
unchanging and still relevant.
And Millard Fillmore is the only
man capable of putting this
country back on the right track
again. We'd rather have a
candidate who's capable and
dead than one who's
incompetent and ill-bred, and
both major parth candidates this
year have proven on many
occasions that they fall into the
latter category.
Burns: Then what you're saying
to the American people is. in
effect: Where have you gone.
Millard Fillmore? Our nation
casts its leaderless eyes on you!
Kennedy: You're right about our
being leaderless today, under the
Ford administration. but we do
know where our candidate has
gone. He has merely gone
underground for a while, waiting
for America to come back to its
senses and re-establish the Whig
Party, stronger than before. Once
the Party gains a strong mandate
from the people, our candidate.
like Emperor Frederick
Barbarossa, will return to us, to
lead our nation on to greater
glory. Can't you see that?
Burns: Not really. But let's get
down to specifics in the Whig
party platform. What exactly

does your party stand for?
Kennedy: We were the original
Big Government people and we
still are. We believe in a strong.
active, positive—thinking.
progressive, innovative central
government, not in government
by veto or government directly
counteracting the wishes of the
people as expressed in Congress.
You might say that we are the
party which directly opposes the
conduct of the Ford
administration. The Democrats
this year have nominated
someone who talks about cutting
down the number of
governmental agencies. of putting
an end to Big Government.
There's no way we can support
him. We have to remain true to
our principles of giving the
taxpayers real services for their
tax dollars.
Burns: What kind of foreign
policy do you think President
Fillmore, would pursue today, if
given his mandate from the
people?
Kennedy: It is hard to predict
what any man will do once he's
in office, but based on his past
wise and prudent policies, I think
I can make some predictions. If
elected, The President would
probably pursue a policy of
benign neglect as far as the
Chinese are concerned. As for
Japan, we need them as allies and
trading partners and we're going
to be their close friends, whether
they like it or not. Another
Commodore Perry expedition

might be in order. The Russians
should be assured that we are not
planning to annex Cuba, no
matter how many Southern
crazies urge us to do it. There's a
real danger of that happening if
Pierce gets in, but the Russians
have nothing to fear from a
Fillmore administration. I think
the Alaska purchase was a bad
idea: it gave the Russians the idea
that we were imperialists, and
they've been edgy ever since.
Burns: What about Eastern
Europe?
Kennedy: President Fillmore has
stated on numerous occasions
that he was in sympathy with the
nationalist movements struggling
for independence from the
Hapsburgs However, this does
not mean that The President
would necessarily invade any of
Emperor Franz Joseph's
territories. That's as far as I'm
willing to discuss the question at
this time. We will not be
blackmailed by either Hapsburg
threats or Croatian terrorists.
Burns: What about Mexico?
Kennedy : There will be no
pardon tor President Santa Ana,
but reparations are due the
Mexican people for the damage
we inflicted on them during the
war we pursued under a
Democratic administration—a
war opposed by Millard Fillmore.
Let's forget the Alamo, and
maybe the Mexicans will forget
Chapultepec. Now is a time for
healing.
Burns: You mentioned American

Blue Jays mauled by Moravian
It doesn't take much to turn a
good football game into a
rout-sometimes just one play.
The Blue Jay gridders found
this out the hard way Saturday
afternoon as they were being
demolished by Moravian College,
40-0.
The play in question occurred
late i n th e second quarter.
Trailing only 12-0, the Jays had
marched from their own thirty to
a. first down at their opponents'
three yard line.
However, a second down pass
Was deflected, intercepted in the
end zone and returned to the
Moravian thirty. From there, the
visitors drove down the field and
scored on a 27-yard touchdown
pass with less than a minute
remaining in the half. The
two -point conversion attempt
Was successful, the lead was
suddenly 70-0 and Hopkins never
really recovered.
"That (the interception) was
definitely the turning point of
the game," JHU head coach
Dennis Cox later commented.
Not scoring that touchdown
hurt because it would have given
OM team alot of confidence for
the second half. That would have
made it a much closer and a
much better game."
A major factor that enabled
Moravian to turn the contest into
a rout was the running abilities of
the opposing- backs. According to

Cox, "They were at least twice as
quick as the Georgetown backs."
These rushing abilities had
become evident early in the first
quarter. Following a Hopkins
punt, Moravian moved eighty
yards in just six plays to take a
6-0 lead. This drive had been
accomplished without a pass and
had featured runs of thirty-four,
ten and twenty-four yards.
Moravian increased their
advantage to 12-0 midway
through the second period.
Mixing their running with an
effective passing game, the
visitors to Homewood marched
seventy yards-the touchdown
coming on a seven-yard scoring
toss.
Following halftime, the game
scenario changed little. The Blue
Jay offense was unable to sustain
itself long enough to move into
the opposing end zone while its
Moravian counterpart, led by the
strong running attack, was able
to equal the output of the first
half.
The score became 26-0 late in
the third quarter as Moravian
culminated an eighty-eight yard,
fourteen play drive. Once again,
the visitors had combined timely
rushing to
passes with the
engineer their second long
scoring effort of the day.
Moravian resorted to their
seemingly unstoppable running
game to score fourteen fourth

period points. Runs of
forty-three and fifteen yards set
up a short scoring plunge midway
through the quarter, while the
final points were put onto the
scoreboard with less than two
minutes to play on a forty-two
yard touchdown run.
"I expected our team to play
better," Cox said. "I knew that
they (Moravian) were a good
team, but I was disappointed that
we didn't play as well as we have
been playing-especially our
defense.
"In football, it's important to
'control the momentum and to
force your opponents to play
your type of game. However, in
this game, we were never in that
position-,we, were always
strugglin on offense."
The Blue Jays (now 2-4) have
three games remaining on the
schedule and, according lo 'the
coach, the team is looking ahead.
"Swarthmore, Dickinson and
Western Maryland will all be
tough games," Cox explained.
Bring on Swarthmore
"We're capable of beating
those teams and we're going to
work very hard to win those
games, though every one of them
will be a dogfight."
The Swarthmore contest is the
next one for the Blue Jays. It will
be played on the Garnet home
field in Pennsylvania this
Saturday.

Put on your Whig

Millard A. Fillmore: the Gerald Ford of his generation
By BIFF BURNS
"May God save the country; for
it is evident the people will
not..."
Millard Fillmore, 1844
(upon learning of the defeat of
the Whig party in the Presidential
election)
As every worthy journal
occasionally requires its share of
what may be termed "filler
material", I have been summoned
back from indolent retirement to
play the role of nay-sayer once
more. I crave the gentle-reader's
indulgence (as I pray whatever
gods there be will forgive my
sub-literary self-indulgence) as I
relate My experiences of a
fortnightpast in the City of
Brotherly Love.
The Comte de Baton, an
eighteenth-century French
naturalist, theorized that native
European species of plant and
animal life would undergo a
Process of degeneration in the
New World because of climatic
change. It is my belief that our
own species has indeed
deteriorated here in North
America, not physically in
Button's sense, but culturally and
Spiritually. I do not claim to
understand the process, but I see
the city of Philadelphia as an
appropriate illustration of its
Workings. For whatever pride
that city may rightly retain is
Justified only by the memory of
its past—and not by the reality of
its present condition.
The shrine of religious
toleration in America, the
birthplace of our Constitution,
the home of Franklin, Rush, and
Rittenhouse-THEN. But look at
Philadelphia 200 years later:
graffiti capital of the nation,
haven for the most brutal hockey
team in the NHL, turf of roving
street gang and more subtle
mafiosi, the home of Mike
Douglas (an archetypal figure of
American mediocrity), nominally
ruled by Frank Rizzo
(representative of another kind
of mediocrity and brutalization,
and far more of a menace to
society than Mike Douglas or
even the Flyers). No sages come
out of this city any more, only
Joey Bishops and David
Brenners. We must have been
doing something wrong to
devolve so far in only 200 years,
one brief cosmic instant on the
Darwinian timetable. I came to
Philadelphia to come to terms
With America's failure and,
incidentally, to watch our two
current major-party Presidential
candidates in their first so-called
debate.
Since I was not invited by the
League of Women Voters (those
self-appointed guardians of our
electoral process) to attend the
debate as either spectator or
questioner. I arrived at the
Walnut Street Theatre on the
morning of October 6 in high
dudgeon—yet prepared to accept
the apologies due me for what
could only have been a
monstrous oversight on the part
of that organization. My outrage
only increased, however, as I
found myself first threatened
with a hatpin and then forcibly
escorted from the Theatre by a
Main Line bluestocking and a
Rizzo bluecoat, respectively.
There is no room for
independent scribes in these
debates; one must have
institutional ties in order "to
count" in our society. As I made
my exit, I noticed Jody Powell
stepping out of a limousine. I

P.

'
diem"

Young Millard: who would have
identified myself, explained my
predicament, and received this
reply: "After that hatchet job
did on us back in New
Hampshire, I'm sorry you got off
so easy (sic) today." (If Mr.
Carter's press secretary had only
known how many crucial ethnic
votes in Northwest Baltimore I
control, his whole attitude would
have changed).
After devouring a mediocre
hoagie in a Broad Street beanery,
I registered at a once-prestigious
hotel formerly patronized by the
late John O'Hara, whose
economy of style and banality of
story line I greatly admired, and
by the late American Legion,
whose politics I despised but
whose courageous military
service should have merited a
much happier fate than the one
they received in my hotel. I made
sure that the desk clerk at the
Bedford-Strathmore (name
changed to protect the jinxed)
assigned me the same room
Pennsylvania Governor Milton
Shapp had recently rented and
lived to proclaim "perfectly
safe", a room, incidentally,
equipped with a color television
set. Like millions of my fellow
Americans living in the range of
UHF stations, I passed up the
debate in favor of viewing the
Jerry Lewis art film "Don't Raise
the Bridge—Lower the River",
secure in the knowledge that my
own cultural priorities were in
proper order. Hence, I cannot
analyze the Philadelphia debate.
The Lord knows in advance that
I'm going to behave this way, and
He's forgiven me already for it.
The morning after the unseen
debates, as I walked down the
hall toward the elevator on my
way to check out, I noticed a
sign on the door of a suite which
cried out that here was
something more urgent to check

out. The sign read: Committee to
Re-Elect the President.
Had I entered a time warp?
Was Old Beady Eyes Back on the
Campaign Trail or was this some
pathetic little propaganda mill
for the true believer, perhaps run
by Rabbi Korff? (Answers: Yes,
No,and No)
Upon entering the
Committee's office and
announcing myself as a political
journalist, I was greeted by John
Pendleton Kennedy IV, an
elderly gentleman farmer from
Talbot County, Maryland (no
relation to that upstart
Massachusetts clan), who
described himself as head of the
campaign as well as Chairman of
the Whig Party National
Committee. The posters hanging
from the walls and the literature
being stuffed into envelopes by
the few teenage volunteers made
it perfectly clear to me that the
focus of the Committee's
activities was neither Richard
Nixon nor his hand-picked
successor but a more remote
accidental President: Millard
Fillmore. In the course of my
ensuing investigation of the
Fillmore for President
movement, I searched in vain for
signs of CIA involvement or the
fine hands of Dick Tuck and
Alan Abel, America's foremost
political hoaxters. After a
lengthy discussion with Chairman
Kennedy, I am convinced of the
utter sincerity and idealism of his
movement. An edited transcript
of our interview follows:
Burns; Isn't running a dead man
for President taking the nostalgia
craze a bit too far? Why nominate
someone who has been in his
grave for more than a century?
Kennedy: First of all, we're
Whigs. Always have been and
always will be. We remain loyal
to the principles of our party and

The President served as
Commander-in-Chief for two and
a half years. While we should
have named our organization The
Committee to Give the President
a Four-Year Mandate on His
Own, that's a hard name to
remember. Besides. we were able
to buy up the letterheads from
another organization at a very
reasonable cost.
Burns: I think we're avoiding the
main issue here. President
Fillmore may have been a
capable man and most deserving
of re-election in his own day, but
the fact remains, sir, that you
can't run a dead candidate for
President and your candidate is
dead. Prove to me that your
party and candidate are
still...well, viable.
Kennedy: As far as being dead
goes, President Fillmore still has
more animation in his Buffalo
sepulchre than Ford showed in
the debate last night.
Burns: I didn't see the debate.
Kennedy: And furthermore, it's
been done before—running a
i posthumous • candidate. In 1872,
Horace Greeley appeared on the
ballot as Democratic and Liberal
Republican candidate for
President although he was dead.
And the Courts didn't hassle him
or try to take his name off the
ballot.
Burns: Yes, but Horace was still
alive at the time of his

God which prevented him from
being with us on Election Day.

A diminishing influence

The Presidential impact on the American economy
By BOB BUCHANAN
Be it one of confidence or
genuine paranoia, the image
projected by the next President
will do as much to influence the
nation's economy as any stand he
may take in accordance with
jobs, spending levels, money
supplies, and the like. But the
impact will likely be less than
what we or the candidates care to
admit.
What matter if that political
• and economic 'bastion of
conservatism -- Gerald Ford -wins, or if voters elect to opt for
the more spendthrift, humanistic
politics and policies of the
Georgian Carter? Will it really
make a difference in the places
where it counts -- on Wall Street.
in welfare and unemployment
compensation lines, and at super
market checkout counters -- if
one man or the other gets the
nod?
In the ballyhoo and electric
atmosphere which pervades the
election week, onlookers tend to
look past the limited effect
which the modern American
Chief Executive can have, both
regarding the economy and the
general condition of national
affairs. We seem to forget that
the executive is but one member
of a web of government, but.
one force matching resources and
wits against the other co-equal
branches of government.
Ultimately, while the next
President will be able to initiate
many pieces of economic
legislation, the Congress will, in
almost all instances, be the final
determiner of .proposals in this
area. The relations with the
Congress which Mr. Carter would
enjoy would place hint in a more
enviable position however, and it
must be pointed out that he
would prove to get more of his
ideas into the governmental

By MIKE DEAK
The trouble with youth is that
it's wasted on the young. --Old
New Jersey adage.
We've come full circle. From
the bombed in the bomb shelter
mentality of the fifties ("Hey
four eyes, let's have a beer bust
Saturday night in your old man's
bomb shelter." "With real girls?"
— Neato-o daddy-o") to the
mindless apathetic paranoia of
the seventies ("Really man who
gives a fuck anymore?") we
Young Americans have returned
to being a race of political
airheads, victims of ideological
vacuums between our ears.
Perhaps with the same naive
optimism that dreamed the
felicitious fantasy of peace ruling
the world in the coming Age of
Aquarius, supposed student
radicals like myself had hoped
the traumatized sixties would
result in a complete
metamorphosis in the nature o f
American existence, not only
Political, but social and cultural
as well. But all that was too
literally a pipe dream; now, to
quote the legendary Professor
Harold Hill, "There's trouble
right here in River City!"
To begin, there is the problem
of perception. No longer is a
personal construct of reality an
acceptable philosophical goal.
After all, who wants to certify a
world of "perpetual murder,
rape, and kidnapping," and in the
same breath (of a misguided
colleague), "marijuana laws are at
best, anachronistic, and at worse,
an invasion of the basic human
right to freedom" (somehow I
don't quite envision Messers.

Jefferson and Franklin had pot
smoking in mind when they
wrote the Declaration of
Independence). Such a
down-trodden juxtaposition of
unequal issues is unfortunately
symptomatic of the intellectual
myopia infecting colleges and
other settings where youth at bay
hang out. If my journalistic
cohort could afford some
corrective lenses, he would surely
not find himself in the middle of
the banana republic rife with
strife and other atrocities that
he describes, but in a plasticene
neon arcade of broken down
pinball machines and
amusements that are no longer
amusing.
On the whole, our youthful
vision of the world outside the
campus is a pretty hopeless one.
In itself, that is not as distressing
as the role we assign ourselves to
play in this aptly named
wasteland. We are not, as some
take fatalistic pleasure in saying,
pawns in a game played by the
powers that be; thinking of this
warped sort presupposes the
existence even of an imaginary
game of chess among the world's
leaders to determine destiny, a
childish concept promoted by
silly movies (Kubrick's "Paths of
Glory" and "Dr. Strangelove" are
notable examples) or kooks who
carry pickets predicting the earth
will meet its doom in twenty-one
days. As any psychologist will
say at the sight of a $20 bill,
paranoia is the prime product of
a guilt complex; in simpler terms,
why should anybody be after me
if I haven't done anything %v/long.
What I'm trying to say in this

article, is that we American
youth have plenty to be guilty
for; not so much for what we've
done, but for what we haven't
done.
Gone are the days when
radicals fed on political Jerry
Rubin sandwiches. All the
activists (the seventies term for
someone crazy enough to
become interested in political
participation) are given now is
piecemeal, an honorary degree

curds of lukewarm political
porridge effective enough to
divert the activist's mind off the
more pressing revolutionary
.issues. The majority of students

revolutionary zeal; we have
accepted the status quo. I think
we all (with the flukish exception
of those political ghouls, The

"Questions, questions...—

It depends on what "life" means....
For most of us, life is a good job,a good wife, a good house,
a good car.
For some (and perhaps for you) this is not enough. The
"good life" somehow is not enough. Life must mean something different: the attempt to live in union with God,to serve
others, to give as totally and as generously as you can.
The Paulists offer a way of life which can satisfy young men
who seek more than the "good life." As a small community
of Catholic priests, we have worked for over a century
throughout the United States and Canada —from Manhattan
to Toronto, from Greensboro to Houston, from Los Angeles
to Fairbanks. Our mission? To speak the message of Jesus
Christ to this modern world: to communicate His shattering
love and overwhelming forgiveness in a time and world where
He so often seems absent.
To do so, we are actively involved in parish work, preaching, adult education, campus ministry, publishing and mass
communications. We are missionaries; we are bridgebuilders. We seek to serve the Gospel in ever new ways.
The Paulist life is not an easy one. But one who dares will
find rewards beyond expectation, satisfactions beyond
dreams. But not complete satisfaction, for we are constantly
searching to make the Gospel real to more people in today's
world.
Don't let your idealism die. Discover what our community
can mean to you.

War is the extension of politics by other ineans, was von
Clausewitz's dictum. The converse i s also true, in my
experience. Politics is the extension of war by other means.
As a pacifist, 1 cannot believe in politics.
I have not always felt thus. I can remember arguing politics
with my friends, when we were in the service. Memory is the
only place where most of them still exist. I was luckier. Still.
I have my political scars from the past on my presently
apolitical self. They're useful reminders, when the political
juices try to flow in me.

You gaze at me, your shroud
mottled with blood, your French
nose aimed at my withered
whiskers, and my heartbeat falls
into cadence with your four and
one-half, concrete Fingers hoofing
against the inscribed tablet that
Aunt Marianne gave us, and you
wonder why I am insane.
Greying hairs caked with
Plaster clog your nostrils like the
gridworks which protected the
gutters of this great city. When I
was an innocent child, before the
noxious fumes escaped (so
indiscreetly) from the
uncondemened phalluses erected
across the river, my siblings and I
would try to fathom the grid, as
Passing through the gossamer of a
tarantula's web, and plant
ourselves safely within the
vomit-spewing veins of this, our
brotherly metropolis.
I use this analogy so that you,
madame, may know that we did
once strive for something
profounder, a Lewis and Clark
expedition through the
circulatory network, to the heart
of the heart herself, but everyone
was too busyfuckinglnjun squaws
(excuse my crudity),so no notice
was taken.
Yes, goddamn it, I take pride
and good ol
American
know-how in m y insanity, but it
IS your task to construe if my
Outward appearance is any
indication of my flesh-covered
entrails. I do not stand
ashamedly in my crusted jockey
Shorts; my star-spangled

pantaloons were sent to Jiffy
cleaners; someone spilt some
Korean catsup along the crotch,
so I must present myself before
you, unable to hide my wizened
widdler
sered by too many
dead- in- the- bed Red Skins. My
dear, you were once such a good
lay yourself! Did you lose your
plastic-plated wedding ring (or
was it just an engagement ring)?
My thoughts muddle; you know
the minds of the criminally
crazy!
Perhaps your intuition is to
some degree valid; perhaps I do
manifest some jealously toward
the phalluses. After the
Millennium, Mr. Sandberg's
"Mass- (if still in one piece) will
finally be able to discern who
was reponsible for the
impregnation. By the way, my
dearest, how was the abortion?
Was the Chink doctor that I
recommended very good? You
really must learn to take more
precaution in your sundry affairs
(i.e., fuckings); you might lose
your virginity.
Remember the first time we
made it and my English nanny
caught us coitus interruptus. You
were so lively, demanding
fireworks for our first born. Well,
I fondly remember the two of us:
me with a knapsack across my
tuxedoes shoulders, ready to axe
my way West and you, big with
the bastard baby. lighting every
step that I took with that nannyfriggin' flame. John Bullshit!
What ever happened to the
pizzazz, that old time religion?

We'd rather have a candidate who's capable and dead
BURNS from page 1
Yankees destroyed it. Our
.northern. wing fell under the
influence of Free Soilers and
closet abolitionists, wild-eyed
tynes who wanted to tear this
country apart and eventually had
their way. But our principles are
unchanging and still relevant.
And Millard Fillmore is the only
man capable of putting this
country back on the right track
again. We'd rather have a
candidate who's capable and
dead than one who's
incompetent and ill-bred, and
both major parth candidates this
year have proven on many
occasions that they fall into the
latter category.
Burns: Then what you're saying
to the American people is. in
effect: Where have you gone.
Millard Fillmore? Our nation
casts its leaderless eyes on you!
Kennedy: You're right about our
being leaderless today, under the
Ford administration. but we do
know where our candidate has
gone. He has merely gone
underground for a while, waiting
for America to come back to its
senses and re-establish the Whig
Party, stronger than before. Once
the Party gains a strong mandate
from the people, our candidate.
like Emperor Frederick
Barbarossa, will return to us, to
lead our nation on to greater
glory. Can't you see that?
Burns: Not really. But let's get
down to specifics in the Whig
party platform. What exactly

does your party stand for?
Kennedy: We were the original
Big Government people and we
still are. We believe in a strong.
active, positive—thinking.
progressive, innovative central
government, not in government
by veto or government directly
counteracting the wishes of the
people as expressed in Congress.
You might say that we are the
party which directly opposes the
conduct of the Ford
administration. The Democrats
this year have nominated
someone who talks about cutting
down the number of
governmental agencies. of putting
an end to Big Government.
There's no way we can support
him. We have to remain true to
our principles of giving the
taxpayers real services for their
tax dollars.
Burns: What kind of foreign
policy do you think President
Fillmore, would pursue today, if
given his mandate from the
people?
Kennedy: It is hard to predict
what any man will do once he's
in office, but based on his past
wise and prudent policies, I think
I can make some predictions. If
elected, The President would
probably pursue a policy of
benign neglect as far as the
Chinese are concerned. As for
Japan, we need them as allies and
trading partners and we're going
to be their close friends, whether
they like it or not. Another
Commodore Perry expedition

might be in order. The Russians
should be assured that we are not
planning to annex Cuba, no
matter how many Southern
crazies urge us to do it. There's a
real danger of that happening if
Pierce gets in, but the Russians
have nothing to fear from a
Fillmore administration. I think
the Alaska purchase was a bad
idea: it gave the Russians the idea
that we were imperialists, and
they've been edgy ever since.
Burns: What about Eastern
Europe?
Kennedy: President Fillmore has
stated on numerous occasions
that he was in sympathy with the
nationalist movements struggling
for independence from the
Hapsburgs However, this does
not mean that The President
would necessarily invade any of
Emperor Franz Joseph's
territories. That's as far as I'm
willing to discuss the question at
this time. We will not be
blackmailed by either Hapsburg
threats or Croatian terrorists.
Burns: What about Mexico?
Kennedy : There will be no
pardon tor President Santa Ana,
but reparations are due the
Mexican people for the damage
we inflicted on them during the
war we pursued under a
Democratic administration—a
war opposed by Millard Fillmore.
Let's forget the Alamo, and
maybe the Mexicans will forget
Chapultepec. Now is a time for
healing.

Blue Jays mauled by Moravian
It doesn't take much to turn a
good football game into a
rout-sometimes just one play.
The Blue Jay gridders found
this out the hard way Saturday
afternoon as they were being
demolished by Moravian College,
40-0.
The play in question occurred
late i n th e second quarter.
Trailing only 12-0, the Jays had
marched from their own thirty to
a. first down at their opponents'
three yard line.
However, a second down pass
Was deflected, intercepted in the
end zone and returned to the
Moravian thirty. From there, the
visitors drove down the field and
scored on a 27-yard touchdown
pass with less than a minute
remaining in the half. The
two -point conversion attempt
Was successful, the lead was
suddenly 70-0 and Hopkins never
really recovered.
"That (the interception) was
definitely the turning point of
the game," JHU head coach
Dennis Cox later commented.
Not scoring that touchdown
hurt because it would have given
OM team alot of confidence for
the second half. That would have
made it a much closer and a
much better game."
A major factor that enabled
Moravian to turn the contest into
a rout was the running abilities of
the opposing- backs. According to

Cox, "They were at least twice as
quick as the Georgetown backs."
These rushing abilities had
become evident early in the first
quarter. Following a Hopkins
punt, Moravian moved eighty
yards in just six plays to take a
6-0 lead. This drive had been
accomplished without a pass and
had featured runs of thirty-four,
ten and twenty-four yards.
Moravian increased their
advantage to 12-0 midway
through the second period.
Mixing their running with an
effective passing game, the
visitors to Homewood marched
seventy yards-the touchdown
coming on a seven-yard scoring
toss.
Following halftime, the game
scenario changed little. The Blue
Jay offense was unable to sustain
itself long enough to move into
the opposing end zone while its
Moravian counterpart, led by the
strong running attack, was able
to equal the output of the first
half.
The score became 26-0 late in
the third quarter as Moravian
culminated an eighty-eight yard,
fourteen play drive. Once again,
the visitors had combined timely
rushing to
passes with the
engineer their second long
scoring effort of the day.
Moravian resorted to their
seemingly unstoppable running
game to score fourteen fourth

period points. Runs of
forty-three and fifteen yards set
up a short scoring plunge midway
through the quarter, while the
final points were put onto the
scoreboard with less than two
minutes to play on a forty-two
yard touchdown run.
"I expected our team to play
better," Cox said. "I knew that
they (Moravian) were a good
team, but I was disappointed that
we didn't play as well as we have
been playing-especially our
defense.
"In football, it's important to
'control the momentum and to

The Alternative Press Information
Centre is a community library serving
the needs of researchers and casual
readers alike. The Centre has available
for public use a wide variety of
literature on such subjects as gay and
women's liberation, third world
movements, the working class
movement, Black liberation,
alternative institutions and culture,
and socialist theory and practice.
